GIULIANIâS WOES MOUNT
ABC News: âThe business relationship between President Donald Trump's private lawyerÂ Rudy GiulianiÂ and the menÂ charged Thursday in a campaign finance schemeÂ is a subject of the ongoing criminal investigation being conducted by federal authorities in New York, according to two sources familiar with the matter.Â The investigation became public after the FBI had to quickly move to arrestÂ Lev ParnasÂ andÂ Igor FrumanÂ before they boarded a flight out of the country from Washington Dulles Airport with one-way tickets. They have been named as witnesses in the ongoing impeachment inquiry into President Trump. The investigation is being conducted by the FBI's New York field office and prosecutors in the Southern District of New York, the same U.S. Attorney's office Giuliani ran before he became mayor of New York.â

Former Ambassador to Ukraine cites Giuliani pressure campaign -Â AP: âFormer U.S. Ambassador to UkraineÂ Marie YovanovitchÂ told lawmakers Friday that President Donald Trump pressured the State Department to oust her from her position. Yovanovitch said in an opening statement obtained by The Associated Press that she was âabruptlyâ recalled in May and told the president had lost confidence in her. She said she was told by an official that there was a âconcerted campaign against meâ and that Trump had pressured officials to remove her for almost a year. âAlthough I understand that I served at the pleasure of the president, I was nevertheless incredulous that the U.S. government chose to remove an ambassador based, as best as I can tell, on unfounded and false claims by people with clearly questionable motives,â Yovanovitch wrote in the statement.â

Report: Trump pushed Tillerson to help a Giuliani client -Â WaPo:Â âPresident Trump sought to enlist then-Secretary of StateÂ Rex TillersonÂ in the fall of 2017 to work with Rudolph W. Giuliani to help stop the prosecution of a Turkish Iranian gold trader represented by the former New York mayor, according to people with knowledge of the request. Trump urged Tillerson in an Oval Office meeting to try to craft a diplomatic âdealâ to stop the U.S. case againstÂ Reza ZarrabÂ on corruption charges in exchange for concessions from Turkey. The request shocked the then-secretary of state, said the people, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to describe private conversations involving the president. At the time, Turkish PresidentÂ Recep Tayyip ErdoganÂ was personally lobbying Trump to get the charges dropped. Trump, in turn, repeatedly raised the topic with Tillerson â including directly in the Oval Office meeting, according to people with knowledge of the episode.â

Pete Sessionâs political revival threatened by Ukraine role -Â NYT:Â âFormer RepresentativeÂ Pete Sessions, a Texas Republican who is seeking a return to Congress, was caught in the fallout of the Ukraine scandal on Thursday when he was referred to in the indictment of two presidential allies accused of campaign finance allegations. Mr. Sessions, who served 11 terms in Congress until he was swept out last year, is described as âCongressman-1â in the indictment ofÂ Lev ParnasÂ andÂ Igor Fruman, who were arrested and charged on Thursday with illegally funneling foreign money to American political candidates and campaigns. The two men are associates ofÂ Rudolph W. Giulianiâ¦ Mr. Sessionsâs appearance in the indictment, which was filed just a week after he announced he would run for Congress in 2020, was an early and potentially damaging blow to his campaign. Mr. Sessions is not named in the indictment, nor is he accused of any wrongdoing. On Thursday, he issued a statement that denied any wrongdoing and said he had no knowledge of the scheme detailed by federal prosecutors.â

Continetti: We are all Ukrainians -Â Free Beacon:Â âFrom Varsity Blues to Jeffrey Epstein, from China and the NBA to Ukraine and Hunter Biden, Americans are taking a crash course on the ways in which powerful people manipulate the system for personal advantage and globalization merges political cultures as well as economies. What has been uncovered as impeachment rolls on does nothing to spur confidence in the integrity of our system. America is exceptional, but our elites are not. Today we are all Ukrainians.â

TRUMP LEGAL TEAM TRASHES GOWDY
Yahoo:Â âThe presidentâs decision to bulk up his legal team with former South Carolina Rep. Trey Gowdy amid a widening impeachment inquiry is drawing criticism from one of his high-profile supporters. On Wednesday morning, the day after news leaked that Gowdy was set to serve as outside counsel to the president,Â Victoria Toensing, a veteran Washington lawyer who has been working with Trumpâs personal attorney, Rudy Giuliani, expressed concern and disbelief that the onetime advocate for congressional oversight would be coming onboard.Â âTrey Gowdy doesnât know s***,â she said. â¦ âHe screwed up the Benghazi hearings, and he came out with the advice to Trump, âWell, if youâve done nothing wrong, just talk toÂ Bob Mueller.ââ Toensing and her husband,Â Joe diGenova, work with Giuliani though they are not officially on Trumpâs legal team.â

And he canât even join until January -Â WashEx:Â âFormer Republican Congressman Trey GowdyÂ cannot join President Trump's legal team until early next year, the president announced Thursday. Speaking to reporters on the South Lawn of the White House, Trump said, âTrey Gowdy is a terrific guy. I think thereâs a problem with, he canât start for another couple of months because of lobbying rules and regulations.â It was only a day afterÂ Jay Sekulow, counsel to the president, announced Gowdy had joined the team to assist with the response to the House Democrats' impeachment inquiry. â¦Â Gowdy, 55, is a former federal prosecutor who retired from Congress on Jan. 3 after representing the 4th Congressional District of South Carolina for four terms. He then rejoined his old white-collar law firm, Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough. Despite his return to the legal profession,Â federal lawÂ prevents Gowdy from taking on Trump as a client in the impeachment fight until Jan. 3, 2020.â DEMS DIVIDED ON TIMING OF IMPEACHMENT VOTE
Politico:Â âHouse Democrats are grappling with whether to take more steps to formalize their impeachment inquiry and silence a chief Republican criticism of their efforts, with competing factions beginning to emerge. President Donald Trump and his allies on Capitol Hill have hammered SpeakerÂ Nancy PelosiÂ for not holding a vote authorizing the Houseâs impeachment proceedings â arguing that without a vote, the entire process is illegitimate.Â Pelosi has refused to cave, dismissing Trumpâs demand last week and insisting it is not required under the Constitution or House rules. And allies close to the speaker say her position hasnât changed, describing the idea as the latest âRepublican canardâ in a series of stall tactics the GOP will employ to protect Trump. â¦ Yet some Democratic lawmakers and aides have begun to say privately â and, to a lesser extent, publicly â that the House should just vote to formalize the inquiry, robbing the GOP of its main talking point. The debate is threatening to cleave Democratsâ unified front as the White House makes the arcane procedural arguments the centerpiece of its impeachment defense.â

House members get an earful from voters back home -Â Politico:Â âThe âMake America Great Againâ hats were in the front row Thursday night at freshman Rep.Â Anthony Brindisiâs first town hall event since Speaker Nancy Pelosi blessed an impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump. But for all the criticism the centrist Democrat faced from pro-Trump voters, the sharper questions came from his own supporters about why he is one of just seven in his caucus who has refused to endorse the impeachment push. â¦ Swing-district Democrats doggedly avoided the impeachment debate when they first got to Washington. Now they canât avoid it. â¦ But at dozens of town halls over the two-week recess, Brindisi and other vulnerable freshmen had to fend for themselves â serving as the partyâs on-the-ground voices on impeachment. Whether they can deliver a message that resonates could determine Democratsâ chances of winning over the public and holding on to their seats and the House majority in 2020.â

Independentsâ support for impeachment jumps 10 points -Â NPR:Â âA slim majority of Americans now approve of the Democratic House-led impeachment inquiry into President Trump, a new NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist poll finds. Fifty-two percent say they approve of the inquiry, while 43% disapprove. That's a slight increase in support from two weeks ago, when 49% approved and 46% disapproved. The numbers are in line with other polls that have been released this week also showing majority support or an increase in support for the inquiry. The uptick in support in the NPR poll comes mostly from a swing among independents. In late September, more independents disapproved of the inquiry than approved, by a 50-44% margin. Now, in a reversal, more independents approve of the inquiry than disapprove, by a 54-41% margin, a net change of 19 points. On the questions of whether Trump should be impeached or removed from office, Americans are split â 49-47% in favor of impeachment and 48-48% on whether the Senate should vote to remove him.â

ROMNEY STEPS UP HIS ROLE FOR GOP
Politico:Â âPresident Donald Trump wants to sidelineÂ Mitt RomneyÂ â but the Utah senator isnât having it. Even as he faces a barrage of attacks from the president and his allies, Romney is mapping out plans to play a central role in 2020 â headlining party events, shelling out cash from his campaign war chest, and hitting up his donor network for vulnerable senators on the ballot next year.Later this month, Romney will take his most aggressive step yet to insert himself into the 2020 campaign when he hosts a New York City fundraiser for Maine Sen.Â Susan Collins, Colorado Sen.Â Cory GardnerÂ and Michigan Senate hopefulÂ John James. All are establishment-aligned figures confronting tough races in swing states. Behind the scenes, Romneyâs team has also begun directing his donors to help GOP candidates in Senate battlegrounds. Romney aides say he's always intended to help in competitive Senate races and that his desire to do so has never been influenced by Trumpâs efforts to ostracize him.â

Dems eye Chelsea Clinton for New York House seat -Â NYT:Â âMs. [Nita]Â Loweyâs announcement set off a wave of speculation about other potential contenders, includingÂ Chelsea Clinton, the daughter of former PresidentÂ Bill ClintonÂ andÂ Hillary Clinton, as well as a state assemblyman,Â David Buchwald. Last year, when asked if she envisioned running for elected office, Chelsea Clinton told The Journal News, which covers the Hudson Valley, that âif someone were to step down or retire,â she would âhave to think if itâs the right choice for me.â Ms. Clinton did not mention any particular office, although she is clearly familiar with Ms. Loweyâs district: Her parentsâ house in Chappaqua, N.Y., is in the district. Ms. Clinton herself does not live in Westchester, but congressional candidates are not required to live in the district they represent. A representative for Ms. Clinton did not return a request for comment. Mr. Buchwald said he would make an announcement within a few days.â

Ocasio-Cortez draws credible primary challenger -Â Fox News:Â âA prominent New York City Democrat filed with the Federal Election Commission (FEC) Thursday to launch a primary challenge for the House of Representatives seat currently held by Rep.Â Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D.-N.Y. City Council memberÂ Fernando CabreraÂ said he believes a moderate Democrat such as himself could beat the socialist Ocasio-Cortez. He plans to target her far-left views and highlight his belief that she is a âno showâ in the district. âOnly a Democrat is going to be able to defeat her, and itâs going to be a moderate Democrat,â Cabrera, who represents a Bronx City Council district, told Politico. âSheâs a no-show in the district. She hasnât brought about anything except division within the party.â âSocialism doesnât work,â Cabrera added.â

Pompeo ally steps aside in Kansas Senate race -Â The Wichita [Kan.] Eagle:Â âA Kansas business leader with longtime ties to Mike Pompeo will not run for U.S. Senate after weighing a bid for months â renewing speculation about whether the secretary of state will enter the race.Â Alan Cobb, the president and CEO of the Kansas Chamber of Commerce, in the past has said he would defer to Pompeo if the chief diplomat decided to mount a campaign. Cobb, a former Koch Industries lobbyist, advised Pompeo in 2014 during a congressional primary battle against former Rep.Â Todd Tiahrt. He made no mention of Pompeo in a lengthy statement Thursday announcing his decision. Cobb said that âafter months of serious deliberation, analysis, and careful and prayerful consideration with friends, colleagues and my family, I have decided that the best place for me to pursue my passion is to remain as the President and CEO of the Kansas Chamber.ââ

Iâm cool with that.Â If you can find one.â âÂ Sen.Â Elizabeth Warrenâs answer during CNNâsÂ Equality Town HallÂ on Thursday night, when asked what she would say to a supporter who believes marriage is between one man and one woman.

FROM THE BLEACHERS

âI need your help. I donât get what is going on with the Syria/Turkey situation. I understand the following: Trump has proclaimed that he is pulling troops from Syria after what has been a long involvement (partnering) with the Kurds. But, that doesnât happen overnight, right? Once Trump announced the pulling of troops, Turkey is waiting on the sideline frothing at the chance to attack. They then attack, even with threats from Trump that they better not or there will once again be sanctions. Now the number of Kurds killed are rolling in, but are our troops still there? If they are, what are they doing? Is there something that Trump picked up on that is going on with the Kurds? The conspiracist side of me thinks he sniffed something out. My husband is an Iowa farmer and I work in crop insurance. We donât have many ties to the military but sure understand how government a lot of the time just doesnât make sense. Any insight would be appreciated.â âÂ EâLise Bracker, Underwood, Iowa


[Ed. note: No conspiracy here, Ms. Bracker. The number of U.S. troops in the disputed area was very small â measured in dozens. They were not a credible threat in terms of actually combating Turkeyâs forces but rather something of a marker. By having the troops there, we were telling the Turks to stay out and leave our Kurdish allies alone. It was a small-scale version of the U.S. forces in South Korea: To fight, the Turks would have had to kill Americans, thereby bring our military down on their heads. Upon the presidentâs order, the U.S. troops were quickly out of the Turksâ zone of aggression. The Americans went to Iraq and other U.S. spots in the region, clearing the way for the Turks to start pummeling their ancient Kurdish enemies.]Â 


âI am a huge fan of the Halftime Report and never miss it! Your struggle to remain fairly balanced is appreciated, especially by this reader who also struggles mightily to find truth and facts amid the bias and innuendo currently being passed off as ânews.âÂ  But I am confused by most of the polls' questions (especially the polls you quote) that seem to ask a compound question: Do you favor impeachment and removal of President Trump? I was under the impression that these are two distinct question.Â  That impeachment is like a grand jury investigation, i.e. a procedure (in the House) designed to decide whether there are grounds for a trial (by the Senate) to decide if removal is warranted or not. Am I wrong?Â  Please explain!Â  And keep up the good work!!!â âÂ Tom Scherer, Udon Thani, Thailand


[Ed. note: This is an excellent question, Mr. Scherer! Different pollsters do indeed ask these questions in different ways. The complexity of the situation is partly to blame. An âimpeachment inquiryâ is not a thing. Itâs like a couple being âpre-engaged.â But some pollsters have been asking about it, which tends to screw things up. Getting respondents to differentiate between an âimpeachment inquiryâ and âimpeachmentâ is quite a lot of hair-splitting for civilians. Our poll does it the right way (obvi) and asks whether voters support impeachment, impeachment and removal or no impeachment. Those are the three constitutional possibilities. InÂ our poll, 4 percent of respondents said they wanted the president impeached but not removed. That adds up to 55 percent favoring impeachment and 51 percent favoring removal.]


âAll my teams have long gone home for the winter. So now we have your traditional Nine in the form of the quite surprising Cardinals playing your hometown Nationals (who should be the Senators and in the American League with Walter Johnson throwing flames, but oh, well). Where do your loyalties lie?â âÂ Mary Carol Miller, Greenwood, Miss.


[Ed. note: Hometown!? Washington, D.C.!? My place of residence, certainly. And I do love living here. But câmon, Doc! My hometown is Wheeling, W.Va. and the Cardinals, whose order I lustily joined as a boy when my family moved to St. Louis for four years, are my baseball team. I admire the Natsâ pluck and am grateful for the chance they are affording me to watch the National League Championship Series in person. But I love the Cardinals and am absolutely over the moon with this yearâs squad. What a bunch! The infield alone may be the greatest since my glory days of fandom in the mid-1980s.Â Matt CarpenterÂ is an absolute rock for the team and the personification of professionalism,Â Paul DeJongÂ is a clutch player (whoever heard of a slugger shortstop?) who seems like he was born to be a Cardinal,Â Kolten WongÂ surfs second base like the pros ride waves at Honoliâi in his hometown andÂ Paul GoldschmidtÂ has shown in his tenacity, play and quality of his character that he is truly in the right uniform. AndÂ YadiÂ is nothing less than a national treasure. So suffice it to say: Viva el Birdos!]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 


âHow âbout them Redbirds! We miss you on Twitter where we could delight in the pure joy emanating from Cardinals gifs, memes, and tweets after a playoff series winâ¦but the mailbag will have to do!â âÂ Jack Whiteman,Â St. Louis

âTHIS IS A NUDGE TO PICK UP THE FUDGEâ
AP:Â âOfficials in a southwest Missouri city are planting small flags in piles of abandoned dog poop as part of a campaign to get residents to clean up after their pets downtown. The Police Department in Springfield, Mo., posted photos of the flags in use on its Facebook page Wednesday. The flags contain messages such as, âIs this your turd? âCuz that's absurdâ and âThis is a nudge to pick up the fudge.â The campaign started this week and the department noted on Facebook that leaving behind a pet's mess in many cases violates a city ordinance. The city's Environmental Services said the flags are made of bamboo and recycled paper and downtown crews will pick them up if they have to clean up pet waste.â

AND NOW, A WORD FROM CHARLESâ¦
